title: Revocable Trust & renting to a relative?
question: My father has a revocable trust. I am trustee and my sister and I are down as 50/50. We each have 3 children listed in the trust as contingent beneficiaries. My father lives elsewhere and has an old house that is currently vacant and in disrepair. My father wants to let this grandson repair the house on my father's dime to make it livable so he (the grandson) can move in to rent it from my father. My father wants to let the grandson rent the house for 50% lower than fair market value compared to other similar rentals in this area. Fair market rent is $3200/mo. The grandson (a contingent beneficiary) who wants to move in is my sisters son.
answers:
It would be an odd revocable trust that listed you and your sister as co-trustees. Nonetheless, so long as the trust is revocable and your father is competent, a current trustee has the duty to follow his instructions. That duty is probably spelled out in the trust if you are a co-trustee.

Bottom line: Your father has no duty to you. However, as a trustee, you have a fiduciary duty to your father.

Unless specified in the trust, a co-trustee may act independently without the consent of the other but always in the best interest of the trustor and vested beneficiary as directed by him.

I would merely echo the above comments, wholeheartedly. I would also advise that your father may well remove you as a beneficiary if you complain too much.
He might also just sell the house to the grandson for less than FMV, which is his right.

"My Dad created a Trust, I am a beneficiary, and that money is mine"

This is an interesting question, because many beneficiaries believe that when their parents create a trust, it creates an absolute promise or contract with the beneficiary, in this case, you! "My dad created this trust" --"I can bank on that money coming to me." This is a common misconception.

So, Your question assumes that your dad, because he named you as a beneficiary, has a contract with you now.

This is what makes Trusts interesting. Your father is both the grantor, the person who put the money and property into a trust, and the trustee, the person who executes the wishes of the grantor.

Because it is revocable, the Trustee can change the terms of Trust at any time. The Trust becomes irrevocable and you become a beneficiary with a realized interest when your father passes away. The new trustee, (you?), would then be responsible for asking for market value rents unless all non contingent beneficiaries agree.

Because he is both the grantor and the trustee, he can make any contract or agreement he wishes.

You wish to stop the grandson transaction, because you are assuming the trust has become a fully realized contract, an irrevocable trust, and that you are losing out in rents payable to the trust entity.
Unfortunately, for all beneficiaries, this is not the case.
It is still your dad's money until he passes away...(Lucky for you, He can't take it with him).

I would cool your jets and just be grateful that he wants to leave you some cash. Unfortunately, right now it is just a revocable, reversible promise....
If you want something more concrete, I would hire an attorney to advise you, and/or have a chat with your dad.

Experience tells me that these trusts can be adjusted at any time....

Your father is still living, right? Your father is still competent, right? He can do whatever he wants with his property by making a proper amendment to his revocable trust. Problem solved, right? If possible, he can use the same attorney who prepared the trust originally. If not possible, any experienced Trust attorney can do the job. The cost should be minimal.

Find/consult/hire a lawyer in your area using the Avvo feature "Find a Lawyer". Make a list of 4-5 having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back from one, go on to the next on your list. Some offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Take us up on it.

Very simply, this is your father's trust and your father's property and he can do whatever he wants with it, including renting out the house to his grandson for less than fair market rent. He can even amend the trust to eliminate you as a successor trustee and/or beneficiary. Once your father passes on and you are the trustee of the trust, feel free to raise the rent on your grandson to fair market value until such time as the trust distributes the trust assets to you and your sister. But be prepared to never speak to your sister or nephew again. Personally and without knowing more about the family dynamics, I think what your father is doing is pretty nice by turning a non performing asset into a performing asset and giving his grandson a place to live at reduced rent in return for fixing the place up.
